topics.body: Is there a name for a phobia for flying projectiles?

"@trashboat":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5427ac9f63687239ae370100#post_5427ac9f63687239ae370100
Same here. It would make the decision more heart-gripping and tense rather than Aunt May taking the bullet. Also, in One More Day, May is willing to *accept* her fate rather than her pleading that she didn't want to die. On top of that, Quesada was willing to erase 20 years of history while JMS, the editor of the book, wanted to wipe out 30 years, including the Clone Saga.
topics.author: 513e68eda4c72d4e3b000164

topics.body:
Here's some news: more and more police officers are having to wear cameras.  While one out of forty in the usa doesn't sound like a lot, five years ago very few police officers wore them.

Personally I support having police officers wear cameras because even though it's not perfect it does reduce the chance of conflict from either the suspect or police officer by a massive amount.

Inb4 someone argues that the least likely event to happen is the most likely event to happen, as in someone arguing that cause there's a one a million chance that a police officer accidentally detains a woman giving birth and on her way to the hospital that because of the new cameras we'll have a epidemic of women giving birth in prison.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

topics.body:
"@Ore-O":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/542820756368726dafe00100#post_542820756368726dafe00100

Really? Damn. 

Also, I got to ask, but how does time move in Marvel? I'm seriously lost there, because they said that time slides, rather than just moves forwards thanks to the speed of which comics are published. Apparently the year at this point in Marvel despite us being in 2014-near 2015, its around 2004 or 2005. But they make references to elections in 2008 and so forth, and then there are gaps in time which no one explains, like Dark Reign was supposedly going for a period of a year, and it ends up only around 2 or 3 months. That there is what I'm baffled at, how the heck do they know what date it is when there are three different comics stating different times?

topics.body:
"@gasmaskangel":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/54283758636872274b110100#post_54283758636872274b110100
When you get down to it the reason for corruption in the government tends to come from things snowballing until you have a department or such that is corrupt.

Person A, B and C may not be corrupt but if person D is a person of authority then chances are persons A, B and C will go with the flow because they're told to.  Or in this case it's called the blue code of silence in that if a fellow police officer does something you know is against the rules there's a unspoken rule that you don't tell on them.

While the police cameras doesn't solve the problem, however chances are the police officer will behave better if they know they are being filmed and thus less chance of conflict.

topics.body:
"@gasmaskangel":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/54283dbb6368725794a10000#post_54283dbb6368725794a10000
My money is on ghost in the shell type thing where all the government organizations and a ton of civilian organizations are monitored.  While the downside is that a lot of people are already monitored the other side is that governments are monitoring themselves at a increased rate. The other other side is that the most common type of cyber attack is hacktivism.

Basically imagine ghost in the shell where all governments monitor themselves and that information is stolen on a regular basis, but there's also laughing men who steal that stolen information to blow the whistle.
